definitions.definition: a person who fights against the government of their country

examples.text: Armed rebels advanced towards the capital.
Some parts of the country fell into rebel hands.
The rebels seized control of the national radio headquarters.
The rebels were based in camps along the border.
The southern parts of the country had fallen into rebel control.
They sent in troops to fight the rebels.
a group of rebels against the emperor
new recruits to the rebel cause
Rebel forces clashed with government troops.

definitions.definition: a person who opposes somebody in authority over them within an organization, a political party, etc.

examples.text: A number of Tory rebels are planning to vote against the government.
The Education Secretary has made further concessions to the back-bench rebels.

definitions.definition: a person who does not like to obey rules or who does not follow generally accepted standards of behaviour, dress, etc.

examples.text: I've always been the rebel of the family.
He was a rebel in his teens but he’s a respectable citizen these days.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French rebelle (noun), rebeller (verb), from Latin rebellis (used originally with reference to a fresh declaration of war by the defeated), based on bellum ‘war’.
